docs.lead_paragraph: In 1965, in an impoverished rural county in the Mississippi Delta, the pioneering physician Jack Geiger helped found one of the nation’s first community health centers. Many of the children Geiger treated were seriously malnourished, so he began writing “prescriptions” for food — stipulating quantities of milk, vegetables, meat, and fruit that could be “filled” at grocery stores, which were instructed to send the bills to the health center, where they were paid out of the pharmacy budget. When word of this reached the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington, which financed the center, an official was dispatched to Mississippi to reprimand Geiger and make sure he understood that the center’s money could be used only for medical purposes. Geiger replied: “The last time I looked in my textbooks, the specific therapy for malnutrition was food.” The official had nothing to say and returned to Washington.In some ways, the United States has come a long way since Lyndon Johnson declared the “war on poverty.” But in others, we’re still at square one. We now have a variety of federally-supported nutrition programs, but the health care system remains senselessly disconnected from the “social determinants of health.” In this regard, the United States has fallen behind the rest of the world. If a politician in India announced a public health plan that neglected malnutrition, he would be ridiculed. Here, leaders make this kind of omission all the time. Almost all of the debate about the 2010 Affordable Care Act was consumed with questions about health care access and quality. But if we really want to improve the health of millions of people, we have to address the conditions that make them sick.

headline.main: Treating the Cause, Not the Illness

docs.abstract: A group is training young volunteers to treat the social factors, like poor nutrition and housing, that make patients sick.
docs.snippet: A group is training young volunteers to treat the social factors, like poor nutrition and housing, that make patients sick.

docs.lead_paragraph: WALLACH--Stanley, Dr. The Paget Foundation announces the death of Dr. Stanley Wallach (82). Dr. Wallach was a founder of The Paget Foundation, the first Chairman of the Foundation's Advisory Medical Panel from 1977-1984, a member of the Foundation Board of Directors from 1990 to his death including serving as Board President for many years. Dr. Wallach was Chief, Medical Service, Veterans Administration Medical Center, Albany, NY from 1973-1983 and Chief, Medical Service, Veterans Administration, Bay Pines, FL, from 1983-1990. He was Professor of Internal Medicine, University of South Florida, from 1988-1992. His military service included active duty in the U.S. Naval Reserve, Medical Corps from 1958-1960 and Captain in the U.S. Naval Reserve for thirty one years. Dr. Wallach served as Director, Endocrinology and Metabolic Bone Disease Center, Hospital for Joint Diseases, New York, NY from 1993-2001. He also served as Chief Executive of the American College of Nutrition from October 1993 to October 2003. He served as President of the American College of Nutrition from 1987-1989 and received its Mastership Award in 1999. Dr. Wallach is survived by Pearl his beloved wife of thirty eight years and his loving family. Dr. Wallach will be cremated. Interment will be at the Bay Pines Veterans Cemetery in St. Petersburg, Florida at 2:15pm Thursday July 28th. A service will take place Friday July 29 at 2:00pm at Temple Beth-El, 400 Pasadena Ave S. St. Petersburg, Florida. The Paget Foundation

docs.lead_paragraph: After the E. coli outbreak in Europe last month — which sickened more than 3000 people and killed at least 50 — it was impossible not to think about irradiation. “What if,” I asked myself, “those little fenugreek seeds had been irradiated?” Might there have been fewer deaths, fewer cases of hemolytic-uremic syndrome (essentially, kidney failure; there were 900), fewer tragic stories?
docs.abstract: Large-scale food irradiation probably makes sense as a safety precaution, but it’s not likely to happen.
docs.snippet: Large-scale food irradiation probably makes sense as a safety precaution, but it’s not likely to happen.
